elements.content: A novel 2D-MOF, [Zn­(L1)­(oba)], an effective heterogeneous H-bond donor catalyst, based on carbohydrazide moiety (L1), was synthesized. Remarkable enhanced catalytic activity was achieved for methanolysis of epoxides by applying two effective strategies: (i) increasing the acidic strength of the H-bond donors and (ii) providing more accessible active sites within the framework.
elements.clean_text: A novel 2D-MOF, [Zn(L1)(oba)], an effective heterogeneous H-bond donor catalyst, based on carbohydrazide moiety (L1), was synthesized. Remarkable enhanced catalytic activity was achieved for methanolysis of epoxides by applying two effective strategies: (i) increasing the acidic strength of the H-bond donors and (ii) providing more accessible active sites within the framework.

elements.content: A novel 2D-MOF containing carbohydrazide moiety with high catalytic performance in methanolysis of epoxides was constructed through modulating the acidic strength of the Lewis acid sites by a target-architecture engineering approach, which provides more effective host−guest interactions along with highly exposed effective active sites in the framework.
elements.clean_text: A novel 2D-MOF containing carbohydrazide moiety with high catalytic performance in methanolysis of epoxides was constructed through modulating the acidic strength of the Lewis acid sites by a target-architecture engineering approach, which provides more effective host-guest interactions along with highly exposed effective active sites in the framework.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), hybrid crystalline materials assembled from extended arrays of organic bridging linkers and various metallic nodes, have caused a revolution to access a remarkable variety of modular and functionalized solid-state materials. Systematic variation of molecular building blocks can provide a remarkable tunability in the properties and functionalities of these assemblies, leading to fascinating developments in diverse practical applications. Crystalline nature, uniform distribution of desired active sites, and accessible channels have made MOF-based materials as promising candidates for heterogeneous catalytic systems. In particular, rational design of effective heterogeneous catalysts with proper guest-accessible sites has caused serious challenges in this field. Versatile supramolecular organocatalysts have been judiciously designed based on using various suitable approaches and applying different intermolecular interactions such as metal–ligand, hydrophobic, electrostatic and hydrogen bond interactions. Urea functionality with double hydrogen-bonding character is broadly utilized in supramolecular organocatalysis field as a favorable alternative to Lewis acid catalysis platforms. However, the efficacy of these type of hydrogen-bond donating systems has been limited due to their inherent tendency to self-aggregation. Incorporation of hydrogen-bond donating functionality into MOFs assemblies provides physically separated Lewis acid sites resulting in effective host–guest interactions in a heterogeneous system, which is an ideal approach to overcome the disadvantages of a homogeneous catalytic system including inefficient catalyst recycling and low catalytic efficiency. Currently, to our knowledge, only a handful of heterogeneous urea-based MOF catalysts as H-bond donating catalyst have been reported, in which the urea moiety is incorporated into the assemblies via predesigned or postmodification approaches. These urea-based frameworks indicate enhanced catalytic activity as compared to their homogeneous analogues in various chemical reactions. Despite all these great advantages, obtaining a heterogeneous urea-based MOF catalyst with a high level of reactivity is restricted due to its inherently low activity based on weak acidic nature of the H-bonds as well as the limited pore size of the framework. In addition, there is no efficient systematic study to understand the relationship between the structure and catalytic performance of urea-containing MOFs. To obtain a more efficient heterogeneous H-bonded urea catalyst, some considerations that must be taken are as follows: (i) modulation of the acidic nature of the Lewis acid sites to obtain more effective host–guest interactions; (ii) providing more accessible active sites to facilitate the catalytic reaction. Recently, 2D hybrid inorganic–organic assemblies have been considered as promising candidates with high performance in various practical fields. Particularly, the existence of abundant accessible active sites, which have been exposed on the surface of the 2D MOF, provides more facile and effective interactions between the substrate and active sites in comparison to the interactions that occurred in confined pores of 3D frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), hybrid crystalline materials assembled from extended arrays of organic bridging linkers and various metallic nodes, have caused a revolution to access a remarkable variety of modular and functionalized solid-state materials. Systematic variation of molecular building blocks can provide a remarkable tunability in the properties and functionalities of these assemblies, leading to fascinating developments in diverse practical applications. Crystalline nature, uniform distribution of desired active sites, and accessible channels have made MOF-based materials as promising candidates for heterogeneous catalytic systems. In particular, rational design of effective heterogeneous catalysts with proper guest-accessible sites has caused serious challenges in this field. Versatile supramolecular organocatalysts have been judiciously designed based on using various suitable approaches and applying different intermolecular interactions such as metal-ligand, hydrophobic, electrostatic and hydrogen bond interactions. Urea functionality with double hydrogen-bonding character is broadly utilized in supramolecular organocatalysis field as a favorable alternative to Lewis acid catalysis platforms. However, the efficacy of these type of hydrogen-bond donating systems has been limited due to their inherent tendency to self-aggregation. Incorporation of hydrogen-bond donating functionality into MOFs assemblies provides physically separated Lewis acid sites resulting in effective host-guest interactions in a heterogeneous system, which is an ideal approach to overcome the disadvantages of a homogeneous catalytic system including inefficient catalyst recycling and low catalytic efficiency. Currently, to our knowledge, only a handful of heterogeneous urea-based MOF catalysts as H-bond donating catalyst have been reported, in which the urea moiety is incorporated into the assemblies via predesigned or postmodification approaches. These urea-based frameworks indicate enhanced catalytic activity as compared to their homogeneous analogues in various chemical reactions. Despite all these great advantages, obtaining a heterogeneous urea-based MOF catalyst with a high level of reactivity is restricted due to its inherently low activity based on weak acidic nature of the H-bonds as well as the limited pore size of the framework. In addition, there is no efficient systematic study to understand the relationship between the structure and catalytic performance of urea-containing MOFs. To obtain a more efficient heterogeneous H-bonded urea catalyst, some considerations that must be taken are as follows: (i) modulation of the acidic nature of the Lewis acid sites to obtain more effective host-guest interactions; (ii) providing more accessible active sites to facilitate the catalytic reaction. Recently, 2D hybrid inorganic-organic assemblies have been considered as promising candidates with high performance in various practical fields. Particularly, the existence of abundant accessible active sites, which have been exposed on the surface of the 2D MOF, provides more facile and effective interactions between the substrate and active sites in comparison to the interactions that occurred in confined pores of 3D frameworks.

elements.content: Regarding all these aspects, an architecture engineering strategy was applied to overcome the limitations of the H-bonded urea catalysts to obtain a more effective catalytic system. In this regard, carbohydrazide precursor was judiciously selected to construct a urea moiety with improved performance as Lewis acid catalyst due to its stronger acidic hydrogens, capable of forming more effective host–guest interactions with various substrates. Moreover, this predesigned urea moiety was applied to construct a novel 2D-MOF, namely, TMU-58, to provide more accessible active sites on the surfaces of the structure to facilitate the catalytic process. To evaluate the catalytic performance of this framework, methanolysis reaction of epoxides was selected. Ring opening of epoxides is a well-known reaction in organic synthesis producing β-alkoxy alcohols as vital precursors in pharmaceutical synthesis. Alcoholysis of epoxides with various Lewis acid sites in MOFs is a challenging process and less explored so far. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a carbohydrazide-based MOF catalyst that provides a facile and proper host–guest interaction through its stronger acidic hydrogens exposed directly on the surface of the catalyst, providing a more efficient catalytic activity in ring opening reaction of various epoxides. The desired urea moiety, (1E,5E)-1,5-bis­(1-(pyridine-4-ylethylidene)­carbonohydrazide) (L1), was synthesized by direct reaction of carbohydrazide with 4-acetylpyridine in absolute ethanol (see Supporting Information, section 1). The 2D-MOF, TMU-58, was successfully constructed by reacting a mixture of zinc nitrate, the predesigned N-donor ligand (L1) and 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid (H 2 oba) at 80 °C under solvothermal conditions (). Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that TMU-58, [Zn­(L1)­(oba)], crystallized in the monoclinic P 21/c space group. The coordination geometry around the Zn­(II) metal center can be considered as distorted square pyramidal in which the equatorial positions are occupied by the nitrogen atom of the N-donor ligand (L1) as well as the three oxygen atoms of two different fully deprotonated dicarboxylate (oba – ) ligands, and the apical site is occupied by the nitrogen atom from a different N-donor ligand (L1) (a).
elements.clean_text: Regarding all these aspects, an architecture engineering strategy was applied to overcome the limitations of the H-bonded urea catalysts to obtain a more effective catalytic system. In this regard, carbohydrazide precursor was judiciously selected to construct a urea moiety with improved performance as Lewis acid catalyst due to its stronger acidic hydrogens, capable of forming more effective host-guest interactions with various substrates. Moreover, this predesigned urea moiety was applied to construct a novel 2D-MOF, namely, TMU-58, to provide more accessible active sites on the surfaces of the structure to facilitate the catalytic process. To evaluate the catalytic performance of this framework, methanolysis reaction of epoxides was selected. Ring opening of epoxides is a well-known reaction in organic synthesis producing β-alkoxy alcohols as vital precursors in pharmaceutical synthesis. Alcoholysis of epoxides with various Lewis acid sites in MOFs is a challenging process and less explored so far. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a carbohydrazide-based MOF catalyst that provides a facile and proper host-guest interaction through its stronger acidic hydrogens exposed directly on the surface of the catalyst, providing a more efficient catalytic activity in ring opening reaction of various epoxides. The desired urea moiety, (1E,5E)-1,5-bis(1-(pyridine-4-ylethylidene)carbonohydrazide) (L1), was synthesized by direct reaction of carbohydrazide with 4-acetylpyridine in absolute ethanol (see Supporting Information, section 1). The 2D-MOF, TMU-58, was successfully constructed by reacting a mixture of zinc nitrate, the predesigned N-donor ligand (L1) and 4,4'-oxybisbenzoic acid (H  2  oba) at 80 °C under solvothermal conditions (). Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that TMU-58, [Zn(L1)(oba)], crystallized in the monoclinic P 21/c space group. The coordination geometry around the Zn(II) metal center can be considered as distorted square pyramidal in which the equatorial positions are occupied by the nitrogen atom of the N-donor ligand (L1) as well as the three oxygen atoms of two different fully deprotonated dicarboxylate (oba  - ) ligands, and the apical site is occupied by the nitrogen atom from a different N-donor ligand (L1) (a).

elements.clean_text: 1  Chemical Structure of H2oba and Carbohydrazide Moiety

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment around Zn­(II) metal center. (b) View of a layer of TMU-58 along a-axis. (c) Representation of 2D sheets with 4-fold interpenetration in TMU-58.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment around Zn(II) metal center. (b) View of a layer of TMU-58 along a-axis. (c) Representation of 2D sheets with 4-fold interpenetration in TMU-58.

elements.content: The carboxylate ligand (H 2 oba) is a nonlinear O-donor ligand and the two carboxylate groups in this ligand exhibit varied coordination modes in the structure: one of them acts as a monodentate ligand (κ1 O), while the other one acts as a bidentate coordinating group (κ2 O, O′). This molecular arrangement results in separate 2D sheets. The methyl groups of the N-donor ligand are also positioned in a syn–syn mode relative to the N–H groups of the urea moiety. A 4-fold interpenetration exists in each 2D sheet, which is responsible for its high stability (c, S1, and S2). Many factors may result in various degrees of interpenetration in these systems. Increasing the length of the organic linker might be responsible for the formation of high interpenetrated network in this structure. The 2D sheets of TMU-58 are packed in parallel fashion and provide a considerable space between the layers, which is appropriate for guest occlusion (b and S3). Further structural analysis revealed that the N–H groups of the urea moiety form double hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group in H 2 oba, resulting in formation of an extended 3D assembly [N3···O2 = 2.879(4) Å; N4···O2 = 2.940(4) Å, ∠N3–H3···O2 = 150.5°; ∠N4–H4···O2 = 147.3°]. PXRD analysis was performed to evaluate the phase purity of as-synthesized TMU-58, which revealed a good agreement with the simulated one (Figure S4). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicated a weight loss of about 7% up to 260 °C, which was related to the removal of solvent molecules. This framework exhibits thermal stability up to 290 °C, subsequently a distinctive weight loss happens in the range of 290–500 °C suggesting the degradation of the host net (Figure S5). BET measurement revealed that TMU-58 is nonporous toward nitrogen gas, and all the experiments were done without further activation.
elements.clean_text: The carboxylate ligand (H  2  oba) is a nonlinear O-donor ligand and the two carboxylate groups in this ligand exhibit varied coordination modes in the structure: one of them acts as a monodentate ligand (κ1 O), while the other one acts as a bidentate coordinating group (κ2 O, O'). This molecular arrangement results in separate 2D sheets. The methyl groups of the N-donor ligand are also positioned in a syn-syn mode relative to the N-H groups of the urea moiety. A 4-fold interpenetration exists in each 2D sheet, which is responsible for its high stability (c, S1, and S2). Many factors may result in various degrees of interpenetration in these systems. Increasing the length of the organic linker might be responsible for the formation of high interpenetrated network in this structure. The 2D sheets of TMU-58 are packed in parallel fashion and provide a considerable space between the layers, which is appropriate for guest occlusion (b and S3). Further structural analysis revealed that the N-H groups of the urea moiety form double hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group in H  2  oba, resulting in formation of an extended 3D assembly [N3⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.879(4) Å; N4⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.940(4) Å, ∠N3-H3⋅⋅⋅O2 = 150.5°; ∠N4-H4⋅⋅⋅O2 = 147.3°]. PXRD analysis was performed to evaluate the phase purity of as-synthesized TMU-58, which revealed a good agreement with the simulated one (Figure S4). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicated a weight loss of about 7% up to 260 °C, which was related to the removal of solvent molecules. This framework exhibits thermal stability up to 290 °C, subsequently a distinctive weight loss happens in the range of 290-500 °C suggesting the degradation of the host net (Figure S5). BET measurement revealed that TMU-58 is nonporous toward nitrogen gas, and all the experiments were done without further activation.

elements.content: TMU-58 displays high catalytic performance in methanolysis of various epoxides. To examine the reaction conditions, the methanolysis of styrene oxide was chosen as a probe reaction. No methanolysis product was observed at room temperature. Then the catalytic reaction was conducted at 60 °C, sampling was done at various time intervals, and the products were analyzed by gas chromatography. All the results are illustrated in . By loading 25 mol % of TMU-58 (equivalent to 0.05 mmol of urea-based moiety) in 3 mL of methanol solution of styrene epoxide (25 mg, 0.2 mmol), 98% of styrene epoxide was converted to the major product (2-methoxy-2-phenylethanol) in just 24 h (entry 1). The molar ratio of the catalyst to styrene epoxide was also screened, revealing that the optimum value of the catalyst is based on 0.05 mmol of urea moiety (entries 2 and 3). Surprisingly by doubling the amount of TMU-58, the efficiency of the catalyst is reduced (entry 3). This occurrence might be attributed to the increased steric hindrance caused by the catalyst, resulting in less effective interaction between the substrates. Moreover, the catalytic activity of the homogeneous urea moiety (L1) was compared to its heterogeneous analogue (TMU-58). By applying 40 mol % of L1 as a homogeneous H-bond catalyst, only 9% of conversion occurred, which is indicative of self-quenching/oligomerization of the homogeneous catalytic system. The reactivity of TMU-58 in methanolysis reaction of other epoxides was also examined. The same optimized reaction conditions were used to perform these catalytic reactions (entries 5–10). TMU-58 revealed less catalytic efficiency in ring opening of these epoxides that could be attributed to the steric hindrance of these bulky substrates, which results in less effective interaction between the H-bond donor catalyst (TMU-58) and the bulky substrates. Moreover by increasing the size of the bulky substrates, their facile diffusion between the 2D layers of TMU-58 is reduced.
elements.clean_text: TMU-58 displays high catalytic performance in methanolysis of various epoxides. To examine the reaction conditions, the methanolysis of styrene oxide was chosen as a probe reaction. No methanolysis product was observed at room temperature. Then the catalytic reaction was conducted at 60 °C, sampling was done at various time intervals, and the products were analyzed by gas chromatography. All the results are illustrated in . By loading 25 mol % of TMU-58 (equivalent to 0.05 mmol of urea-based moiety) in 3 mL of methanol solution of styrene epoxide (25 mg, 0.2 mmol), 98% of styrene epoxide was converted to the major product (2-methoxy-2-phenylethanol) in just 24 h (entry 1). The molar ratio of the catalyst to styrene epoxide was also screened, revealing that the optimum value of the catalyst is based on 0.05 mmol of urea moiety (entries 2 and 3). Surprisingly by doubling the amount of TMU-58, the efficiency of the catalyst is reduced (entry 3). This occurrence might be attributed to the increased steric hindrance caused by the catalyst, resulting in less effective interaction between the substrates. Moreover, the catalytic activity of the homogeneous urea moiety (L1) was compared to its heterogeneous analogue (TMU-58). By applying 40 mol % of L1 as a homogeneous H-bond catalyst, only 9% of conversion occurred, which is indicative of self-quenching/oligomerization of the homogeneous catalytic system. The reactivity of TMU-58 in methanolysis reaction of other epoxides was also examined. The same optimized reaction conditions were used to perform these catalytic reactions (entries 5-10). TMU-58 revealed less catalytic efficiency in ring opening of these epoxides that could be attributed to the steric hindrance of these bulky substrates, which results in less effective interaction between the H-bond donor catalyst (TMU-58) and the bulky substrates. Moreover by increasing the size of the bulky substrates, their facile diffusion between the 2D layers of TMU-58 is reduced.

elements.content:
Methanolysis of Various Epoxides by <bold>TMU-58</bold>

Conversion [%] of various epoxides in methanolysis reaction. Conditions: styrene oxide (25 mg, 0.2 mmol), catalyst (0.05 mmol of urea moiety, 25 mol %), t = 60 °C, and 3 mL of methanol.

With 0.1 mmol of catalyst.

With 40 mol % of homogeneous urea moiety (L1).

No obvious change was observed in surface morphology of TMU-58 after conducting the catalytic reactions (a,b). The reusability of the catalyst was also examined. After completion of the reaction after 24 h, the catalyst was filtered off, washed with methanol for three times, and dried at room temperature. The methanolysis reaction was conducted by the same catalytic condition. The catalytic efficiency was reduced to 80% of styrene oxide conversion after two cycles. The PXRD patterns of the recovered catalyst is identical to the as-synthesized one (). Moreover, the SEM images of TMU-58 revealed no obvious change after the recovery process (c).
elements.clean_text: No obvious change was observed in surface morphology of TMU-58 after conducting the catalytic reactions (a,b). The reusability of the catalyst was also examined. After completion of the reaction after 24 h, the catalyst was filtered off, washed with methanol for three times, and dried at room temperature. The methanolysis reaction was conducted by the same catalytic condition. The catalytic efficiency was reduced to 80% of styrene oxide conversion after two cycles. The PXRD patterns of the recovered catalyst is identical to the as-synthesized one (). Moreover, the SEM images of TMU-58 revealed no obvious change after the recovery process (c).

elements.content: SEM images of TMU-58: (A) as-synthesized, (B) after catalytic reaction, and (C) after recovery process.

elements.content: To confirm the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst, a hot filtration test along with ICP analysis was also performed. The catalyst was filtered off after the methanolysis reaction of styrene oxide proceeded for 12 h. No further product was detected after removing the catalyst from the solution and conducting the reaction mixture at 60 °C for a further reaction time of 12 h. In addition, the ICP results demonstrated that the metal concentration is very low in the filtrate, confirming the heterogeneous nature of TMU-58. All these observations verify the organocatalyst character of the H-bond urea moiety in the framework as well as declining the Lewis acid catalytic role of the zinc center in activation of epoxides.
elements.clean_text: To confirm the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst, a hot filtration test along with ICP analysis was also performed. The catalyst was filtered off after the methanolysis reaction of styrene oxide proceeded for 12 h. No further product was detected after removing the catalyst from the solution and conducting the reaction mixture at 60 °C for a further reaction time of 12 h. In addition, the ICP results demonstrated that the metal concentration is very low in the filtrate, confirming the heterogeneous nature of TMU-58. All these observations verify the organocatalyst character of the H-bond urea moiety in the framework as well as declining the Lewis acid catalytic role of the zinc center in activation of epoxides.

elements.content: The first step for ring opening reaction of epoxides is activation of the oxygen atom in the epoxide. The oxygen atom of the epoxide is catalytically activated by forming a double hydrogen bond between the NH groups of the carbohydrazide moiety and the oxygen group of the epoxide. Methanol acts as a nucleophile and attacks the more substituted carbon in the epoxide. Thereby the ring opening reaction might be considered as an SN1-type reaction.
elements.clean_text: The first step for ring opening reaction of epoxides is activation of the oxygen atom in the epoxide. The oxygen atom of the epoxide is catalytically activated by forming a double hydrogen bond between the NH groups of the carbohydrazide moiety and the oxygen group of the epoxide. Methanol acts as a nucleophile and attacks the more substituted carbon in the epoxide. Thereby the ring opening reaction might be considered as an SN1-type reaction.

elements.content: TMU-58 as a 2D heterogeneous H-bond catalyst with strong acidic Lewis sites demonstrates high catalytic performance in activation of epoxides when compared to 3D H-bond organocatalyst MOFs. The conversion of styrene epoxide in these systems (TMU-18 and TMU-19) were only 35 and 31% after 24 h, respectively, and they reach to 100 and 95% conversion of styrene epoxide to 2-methoxy-2-phenylethanol after 140 h, respectively. Moreover, TMU-58 is a more effective catalyst for activation of bulky epoxides due to its stronger acidic hydrogens (, entries 5–10). All these observations confirmed that we succeeded to construct a high efficient catalyst by applying an architecture engineering strategy based on the modulation of the acidic strength of the H-bond donors by introducing electron withdrawing groups and providing more accessible active sites within this 2D-MOF ().
elements.clean_text: TMU-58 as a 2D heterogeneous H-bond catalyst with strong acidic Lewis sites demonstrates high catalytic performance in activation of epoxides when compared to 3D H-bond organocatalyst MOFs. The conversion of styrene epoxide in these systems (TMU-18 and TMU-19) were only 35 and 31% after 24 h, respectively, and they reach to 100 and 95% conversion of styrene epoxide to 2-methoxy-2-phenylethanol after 140 h, respectively. Moreover, TMU-58 is a more effective catalyst for activation of bulky epoxides due to its stronger acidic hydrogens (, entries 5-10). All these observations confirmed that we succeeded to construct a high efficient catalyst by applying an architecture engineering strategy based on the modulation of the acidic strength of the H-bond donors by introducing electron withdrawing groups and providing more accessible active sites within this 2D-MOF ().

elements.content: Comparison of catalytic activity of 3D-MOF and 2D-MOF in methanolysis of styrene epoxide.
elements.clean_text: 4  Comparison of catalytic activity of 3D-MOF and 2D-MOF in methanolysis of styrene epoxide.

elements.content: DFT calculations were also performed to calculate the pK a values for urea and carbohydrazide moieties with B3LYP/6-311++(d,p) basis set. Because of the existence of nitrogen in the structure and due to its electronegativity as well as having free electrons, polarization functions (d,p) are needed to be used. The corresponding anions were also investigated, so we need to add diffuse functions to the basis set to obtain more accurate data. The possible conformers were also searched to obtain the minimum global. The data were then optimized and the frequencies were calculated. Moreover, thermodynamic values were obtained from frequencies data.
elements.clean_text: DFT calculations were also performed to calculate the pK a values for urea and carbohydrazide moieties with B3LYP/6-311++(d,p) basis set. Because of the existence of nitrogen in the structure and due to its electronegativity as well as having free electrons, polarization functions (d,p) are needed to be used. The corresponding anions were also investigated, so we need to add diffuse functions to the basis set to obtain more accurate data. The possible conformers were also searched to obtain the minimum global. The data were then optimized and the frequencies were calculated. Moreover, thermodynamic values were obtained from frequencies data.

elements.content: For the reactions of acid dissociation (HA(aq)→A– (aq) + H+ (aq)), pK a can be defined as follows: p K a = − log K a K a = [ A ( a q ) − ] [ H ( a q ) + ] [ H A ( a q ) ] pK a is then calculated by using the following equations: p K a = Δ G a q R T ln ( 10 ) Δ G aq = Δ G gas + ΔΔ G sol where Δ G gas = G gas ( H + ) + G gas ( A − ) − G gas ( HA ) and Δ G sol = G sol ( H + ) + G sol ( A − ) − G sol ( HA ) In the above equations, ΔG aq is defined as the overall change of free energy for the reaction in solution, ΔG gas is referred to the change of free energy in gas-phase, and ΔG sol is defined as the change in free energy of solvation ( and .

These calculations confirmed that the carbohydrazide moiety has more acidic hydrogens in comparison to urea moiety.

In conclusion, a 2D-MOF with an effective H-bond donor organocatalyst based on carbohydrazide moiety was designed, and its efficiency in methanolysis of epoxides was evaluated. Our design strategy was focused on target-architecture engineering to obtain a high-efficiency catalytic system. To achieve this goal, carbohydrazide moiety was chosen due to its stronger acidic hydrogens in comparison to urea, capable of forming more effective host–guest interactions with various substrates. Moreover, a 2D structure was constructed based on this carbohydrazide moiety to provide more accessible active sites for proceeding the catalytic reaction more efficiently.
elements.clean_text:
These calculations confirmed that the carbohydrazide moiety has more acidic hydrogens in comparison to urea moiety.

In conclusion, a 2D-MOF with an effective H-bond donor organocatalyst based on carbohydrazide moiety was designed, and its efficiency in methanolysis of epoxides was evaluated. Our design strategy was focused on target-architecture engineering to obtain a high-efficiency catalytic system. To achieve this goal, carbohydrazide moiety was chosen due to its stronger acidic hydrogens in comparison to urea, capable of forming more effective host-guest interactions with various substrates. Moreover, a 2D structure was constructed based on this carbohydrazide moiety to provide more accessible active sites for proceeding the catalytic reaction more efficiently.
